hasDitaContent.@value: Both delamanid and amifampridine prolong the QT interval. Most manufacturers advise avoiding the use of two or more drugs that are associated with QT prolongation. Increasing age, female sex, cardiac disease, and some metabolic disturbances (notably hypokalaemia) predispose to QT prolongation.

hasDitaContent.@value: Both delamanid and inotuzumab ozogamicin prolong the QT interval. Most manufacturers advise avoiding the use of two or more drugs that are associated with QT prolongation. Increasing age, female sex, cardiac disease, and some metabolic disturbances (notably hypokalaemia) predispose to QT prolongation.

hasDitaContent.@value: Both delamanid and vernakalant prolong the QT interval. Most manufacturers advise avoiding the use of two or more drugs that are associated with QT prolongation. Increasing age, female sex, cardiac disease, and some metabolic disturbances (notably hypokalaemia) predispose to QT prolongation.

hasDitaContent.@value: Vilanterol is predicted to cause hypokalaemia (potentially increasing the risk of torsade de pointes) when given with delamanid. Manufacturer makes no recommendation.

hasMessage.hasTextContent: Vilanterol   is predicted to   cause   hypokalaemia (potentially increasing the risk of torsade de pointes) when given with   delamanid .  Manufacturer makes no recommendation .

hasDitaContent.@value: Voriconazole very slightly increases the exposure to delamanid. Manufacturer advises caution and monitor ECG.
